items.title: appimage-run: Add pipewire support

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Added configPackages options to both services.pipewire and services.pipewire.wireplumber. Packages specified in these options have their relevant files (e.g. share/pipewire/pipewire.conf.d/*) combined in store path generated by pkgs.buildEnv and linked to /etc/.
Pipewire extraConfig options also get added to this store path in the appropriate locations.

Added extraLv2Packages options to the options of both services for packages providing lv2 plugins required by filter chains the user set up in their pipewire/wireplumber config files. These get added to the LV2_PATH of the service they were specified for. In addition, packages in configPackages can specify passthru.requiredLv2Packages to have them included in the path as well.

In the case of wireplumber, added config and lv2 packages get added for pipewire as well, since config packages for wireplumber are likely to have config files for pipewire as well.

For now my main use case for this is asahi-audio (my setup for that is not yet clean enough to upstream), but I'm sure that as time goes on, other packages will pop up to configure filter chains or similar things. With these options, adding them to nixpkgs should be easy and using them should be easy for users as well.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)

  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.05 Release Notes (or backporting 23.05 and 23.11 Release notes)

    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

I've tested these changes locally with my yet to be upstreamed asahi-audio package and the config files are put in the right places, and lv2 packages are found by wireplumber/pipewire. The existing nixos default config files for pipewire are also present.

items.title: nixos/pipewire: add configPackages options

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Gate support for the gstreamer-device-provider behind the gstreamerSuppert flag. gstreamer-device-provider requires glib-2.0 as well as all the gstreamer dependences which are only pulled in when gstreamerSupport is enabled.

Resubmitting PR #280736 due to reviewers being added during rebase.

obs-studio-plugins.obs-pipewire-audio-capture
Instructions to test this update (click to expand)

Either download from Cachix:

nix-store -r /nix/store/sgn2gr68dv0hjx4jy9kysf5nk05nawgp-obs-pipewire-audio-capture-1.1.3 \
  --option binary-caches 'https://cache.nixos.org/ https://nix-community.cachix.org/' \
  --option trusted-public-keys '
  nix-community.cachix.org-1:mB9FSh9qf2dCimDSUo8Zy7bkq5CX+/rkCWyvRCYg3Fs=
  cache.nixos.org-1:6NCHdD59X431o0gWypbMrAURkbJ16ZPMQFGspcDShjY=
  '

(The Cachix cache is only trusted for this store-path realization.)
For the Cachix download to work, your user must be in the trusted-users list or you can use sudo since root is effectively trusted.

Or, build yourself:

nix-build -A obs-studio-plugins.obs-pipewire-audio-capture https://github.com/r-ryantm/nixpkgs/archive/9571ff646f4284578b5f3cbd34e74875b13a5f7c.tar.gz

Or:

nix build github:r-ryantm/nixpkgs/9571ff646f4284578b5f3cbd34e74875b13a5f7c#obs-studio-plugins.obs-pipewire-audio-capture

After you've downloaded or built it, look at the files and if there are any, run the binaries:

ls -la /nix/store/sgn2gr68dv0hjx4jy9kysf5nk05nawgp-obs-pipewire-audio-capture-1.1.3

items.title: obs-studio-plugins.obs-pipewire-audio-capture: 1.1.2 -> 1.1.3

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Since version 2.3.0, fluidsynth includes a pipewire audio driver. In fact, it's configured to build with pipewire driver support by default, but it needs to be able to find libpipewire during configuration of course. This PR just includes libpipewire so nix now builds fluidsynth with the pipewire driver.

(Note: I had hoped that including pipewire.lib in buildInputs would have worked, but only pipewire worked, not pipewire.lib.)

I wasn't able to run nixpkgs-review, since evulation took up so much memory it blew up my 32GB workstation.

items.title: pipewire-screenaudio: init at 0.3.2

items.content_html:
Description of changes

In order to successfully connect bluetooth audio devices, pipewire must be running already which it might not when socketActivation is enabled.
-> disabling socketActivation is a better default as it provides the more stable user experience

items.title: nixos/pipewire: disable socket activation by default

items.content_html:
The NixOS pipewire module places its alsa compatiblity configuration in
/etc/alsa/conf.d/ instead of /etc/asound.conf. This commit enables
applications running in a fhs environment to use alsa on systems
running pipewire.

This is heavily copied from #129846

Motivation for this change

items.title: build-fhs-user-env: add compatibility for pipewire alsa emulation

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Replace ALSA in the comments of the nixos-generate-config generated config with a minimal PipeWire config, for several reasons:

  • PipeWire is a useful default for many users, irrespective of display server
  • The use of ALSA on most environments is limited in comparison to PulseAudio or PipeWire
  • Users erroneously think that options.sound.enable is related to "enabling sound", so they enable it even when using PulseAudio or PipeWire
